intro: Platycodon grandiflorus var. candolleanus, commonly known as the Korean bellflower, is a perennial herb native to Korea and parts of East Asia. It is characterized by its distinctive bell-shaped flowers that range in color from blue to purple, typically blooming in late summer. The plant has lance-shaped, hairy leaves and produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small seeds. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and borders. Its ornamental value is enhanced by its ability to attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
